Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: An attorney in a case before you has just cited a new appellate court decision from last week that could be relevant. You need to review it before the next session.
Story:
My phone buzzed with a message from Sam, my closest friend. His reply was curt, almost cold—he’d clearly misread the tone of my earlier text. I could picture him, frowning at his screen, probably thinking I was annoyed with him. As his friend, I knew I should call him right away, clear things up before the misunderstanding grew. That’s what friends do: communicate, resolve things before they fester.

But just as I reached for my phone, my clerk knocked, handing me a printout. “Counsel just cited a new appellate decision from last week,” she said. “You’ll want to review it before tomorrow’s session.” As a judge, I’m expected to be thorough, to stay current with every legal shift. The attorneys, the parties—they all rely on me to be prepared, impartial, and up-to-date.

I stared at the printout, then at my phone. My friend needed me now, but so did my courtroom. The weight of both roles pressed in, each demanding my immediate attention, each with consequences if I delayed. My heart pounded as I sat, torn between the call I needed to make and the case I needed to read.
